title-group.article-title: Unusual vegetation stability in a lowland pine forest area (Doksy region, Czech Republic)

author-notes.corresp: Jan Novák, Department of Botany, Faculty of Sciences, University of South Bohemia, Branišovská 31, CZ-37005 České Budějovice, Czech Republic. Email: prourou@gmail.com

abstract.p: Although the Holocene is characterized by prominent vegetation changes, some vegetation types can reveal surprising stability. We studied Holocene woodland history in a sandstone pseudokarst area (Doksy region, Northern Bohemia, Czech Republic). Twelve soil profiles collected under native or semi-cultural pine forests were analyzed using anthracological methods. In seven of them, the age of profile bases was established using radiocarbon dating. All analyzed samples show a high degree of mutual similarity of species composition regardless of the site or the depth of the sampled soil layer, as well as a good concordance between the composition of fossil and contemporary vegetation. Forest vegetation dominated by Pinus sylvestris with a low but regular occurrence of Picea abies, Quercus sp. and Vaccinium sp. has prevailed since late Boreal up to the present. No considerable vegetation changes were detected during this period, except for succession after fire events. A high content of charcoal within soil profiles indicates that the study area has been affected by forest fires through a substantial part of the Holocene. Recurrent wildfires probably represented a crucial factor sustaining pine forests by cyclic succession, although the relative contribution of human versus natural causes of fire cannot be assessed. In earlier phases of the Holocene, the prevalence of pine in the local vegetation was revealed using palynological data, so that we can conclude that the pine-dominated forests ecosystem existed during the entire Holocene in the study area. This pronounced vegetation stability contrasts sharply with the changeable historical vegetation of Central European lowlands.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Vegetation changes are a fundamental feature of historical landscape development. Indeed, long-term vegetation development is characterized by time periods of abrupt species expansions and similarly abrupt declines. However, such periods often alternate with calm phases in which vegetation changes are minor and marginal, or large but cyclic and reversible. These stages show features close to some concepts of vegetation stability (Grimm and Wissel, 1997; Turner et al., 1993). The survival of existing species populations during these stages results in the preservation of older states of vegetation.

Vegetation stability is less striking and less easily detectable on the Holocene timescale than are vegetation changes. This may be the reason why palaeobotanical studies deal with changes more prevailing during the Holocene in Europe, the long-term stability of forest vegetation is evident and common place in the boreal parts of northern Europe, where the number of species invasions and extinctions has been low, and human influence has been rather weak and/or tardy, so that pine or spruce boreal forests have persisted during the forested phase of the Holocene over large areas (Berglund et al., 1996). However, the vegetation history of the European temperate area is characterized by permanent and striking vegetation changes corresponding with the development of climate and human impact. These changes are shown both in overall surveys (Berglund et al., 1996; Lang, 1994) and in the vast majority of studies devoted to the vegetation history of individual localities.

The opinion that some vegetation types are relicts of earlier phases of the Holocene is mostly supported by biogeographical and/or ecological evidence (Chytrý, 2007). However, the survival of a particular vegetation type in a given locality during the Holocene is in general poorly understood, and direct palaeobotanical evidence of the relict status of plant communities is scarce. The lack of evidence may be partly explained by the abundance and nature of available pollen analytical evidence. Palynological interpretations of terrestrial vegetation are necessarily somewhat distorted (Ritchie, 1995) as their data are gathered mostly from wetland habitats, and samples include pollen assemblages from a large and poorly defined spatial scale. Despite the effort to overcome this problem (e.g. Gaillard et al., 2008), palynology is thus often unable to distinguish the former occurrence of a single polydominant community from a tessellated pattern of more monodominant ones.

More plausible results can be attained if pollen analysis is supplemented by charcoal analysis. Pedoanthracological data describe the local vegetation, because the dispersal of charcoal by wind is limited, particularly for fragments larger than 400 μm, which are determinable and datable (e.g. Blackford, 2000; Clark et al., 1998; Lynch et al., 2004). Moreover, charcoal is found in terrestrial habitats with no or poor pollen preservation, so that this approach is suitable for reconsturcting local vegetation history in terrestrial habitats (Poschlod and Baumann, 2010).

The origin and history of Central European pinewoods dominated by Pinus sylvestris are nearly unknown. The bulk of the palynograms shows that pine is present throughout the whole Holocene period as a dominant or co-dominant species. Its prevalence is conspicuous in particular in palynograms from nutrient-poor localities with boreal or continental climate. Pine is one of the most frequent species also in summary palynograms compiled for the lowland, highland and mountain belts of the Czech Republic (Kuneš et al., 2009). However, these data can hardly reveal vegetation patterns at local spatial scales, nor the composition of constituent stands where pine occurs. Furthermore, pine produces abundant long-distance dispersed pollen, which strongly distorts local information.

This paper introduces a case study of striking vegetation stability in a forested area throughout the Holocene. Our study area was chosen based on a preceding hypothesis on its relict status derived from biogeographic data (endemism and the exclave occurrences of some boreo-continental species). We present the results of soil charcoal analysis (identification, quantification and dating) that allow us to reconstruct species composition, and also consider the role of fire in the development of the pinewoods during the last few millennia.

sec.title: Study area
sec.p: The Doksy region (Northern Bohemia, Czech Republic) is a forested area with relatively little permanent open land such as rocks and swamps (Figure 1). Forests covering c. 300 km2 form an enclave which is sharply separated from the surrounding landscape characterized by the prevalence of arable land.

caption.p: Location of the study area and sites (pedoanthracological profiles K1-7, S1-4, W1).

sec.p: The area is a sandstone pseudokarst in the last stage of development. Flat or gently sloped tablelands and shallow peaty basins prevail over rocky sandstone hummocks and sporadic volcanic hills (Demek, 1987). There are several hills higher than 500 m, but most surfaces range from 270 to 300 m above sea level. The Cretaceous sandstones forming the pseudokarst are siliceous, in some cases cemented also by carbonate or iron (Czudek, 1972).

The soils are generally either sandy or peaty and their essential feature is a strong deficiency in the clay component and available nutrients. According to soil maps (Němeček et al., 2008), humus-iron podzols, arenic cambisols and arenic regosols are the most common soils on sandstone bedrock. Depressions are largely filled up by sandy or peaty deposits, whereas gley soils are restricted to the margins of the region, resulting from an influx of flood loam from the surrounding landscape.

The area falls into the humid, continental part of central Europe, moreover, the continental features are more pronounced in the local climate. The period of vegetative growth is rather warm and dry, similarly to adjacent lower parts of the Czech Basin. Mean annual precipitation is 635 mm, but only 364 mm in the growing season. Mean annual air temperature is 7.3°C, but the average annual maximum temperature is 31.5°C. On the other hand, extremes of winter climate resemble conditions of highlands at altitudes of 700–800 m a.s.l. Frost periods occur from the beginning of October to the beginning of May, apparently retarding the growing season. Mean temperature below zero lasts from the beginning of December to the end of February. The annual average minimum temperature is 20.5°C (Tolasz et al., 2007).

At present the area is predominantly forested. Woodland comprises mostly Scots pine (Pinus sylvestris, 68%) and spruce (Picea abies, 16%) according to web data by the local forestry enterprise (Anonymous, 2006). Pine dominates on sandy soils and partly on fen substrata. Beech (Fagus sylvatica, 6%), birch (Betula pendula, 5%) and oak (Quercus petraea and Q. robur, 2%) are also abundant in the area under study.

The area borders on agricultural landscapes abundant in sites of ancient settlement from the Mesolithic, Neolithic, Eneolithic, Bronze Age, Hallstatt and La Tène periods, according to Archaeological Database of Bohemia (Kuna, 2002). Colonization has been the most intensive since the Middle Ages (13th century). However, the study area itself shows different human settlement dynamics (Meduna and Sádlo, 2009). Attempts to colonize the forested sandstone pseudokarst were rather local and temporary in all periods. The evidence of ancient colonization in the forest is poor and restricted to special sites such as rock shelters. In the Medieval and modern periods, the forested area was affected for example by hunting, woodcutting, glass and charcoal production or the local mining of iron ore. In the 20th century, the long-term existence of a military training area disturbed the cultural rather than the natural aspects of the landscape. It has mainly led to a considerable decline in human impact and an extensive restoration of natural processes. Currently, the study area is influenced mainly by conervation (e.g. the maintenance of protected areas) and forestry (e.g. the gradual conversion of semi-natural pine forest into pine plantations).

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: In total, 12 soil profiles were sampled for the pedoanthracological study. The sampling sites are described in Table 1. Profiles were dug in a c. 9 km long strip within hilly sandstone terrain (Figure 1, Table 1). The excavated soils consist of a high content of sand (80–95%) and raw humus. From each soil profile, samples (10 l of fine-grained soil) from different depths according to visible layers were taken. Maximum sampling depth reflected the bedrock in deeper parts of soil horizons.

fn.p: Spec anth: specific anthracomass (mg/kg); %conif: % proportion of coniferous species in anthracological sample; Num char sp: number of charcoal species in the site; Num rec: number of woody species in 100 m2 of recent vegetation; Rec veg: recent vegetation cover.

sec.p: In addition, charcoal and pollen records from a profile called Voroněž were studied. This profile is situated in a peat accumulation at the foot of a forested sandstone cliff (GPS 50°35′ 7.1561264"N; 14°43′28.1663132"E, 275 m a.s.l.). Samples were collected in 2009 from the wall of a pit that had been dug manually.

The extraction of charcoal from the soil and peat sediment followed the standard flotation and wet sieving procedure (Jacomet and Kreuz, 1999), using staggered sieves with mesh size of 1 mm. Charcoal analysis was performed only on fragments from the largest fraction (>2 mm). Charcoals were identified using an episcopic microscope with 200–500× magnification and a reference collection. Additional standard identification keys were also used (Greguss, 1972; Schweingruber, 1990).
Individual taxa were weighed with an accuracy of 0.001 g, and soil anthracomass (mg charcoal per kg of soil, Talon et al., 1998) was determined from charcoals bigger than 2 mm.

Seven samples were submitted to the Center for Applied Isotope Studies, University of Georgia, for radiocarbon dating by accelerator mass spectrometry (AMS). All radiocarbon dates were calibrated using the OxCal program (Bronk Ramsey, 2001).

Sediment samples for pollen analysis were treated by acetolysis after pre-treatment in cold, concentrated HF for 48 h. Pollen was determined by light microscope at a magnification of 400x. Usually more than 300 pollen grains were counted per sample. Microscopic charcoal particles larger than 40 µm2 were counted during pollen analysis (Kangur, 2002). The area of a charcoal particle was estimated by multiplying the lengths of the longest and shortest axes. The stratigraphic diagram was created using Tilia 1.5.12.
Charcoal samples for AMS 14C dating (Table 2) were taken from the basal layer of profiles. One random charcoal piece per base layer was dated.

caption.p: List of radiocarbon dates. Calibration of radiocarbon data to calendar years was computed using the OxCal program (Bronk Ramsey, 2001). Calibrated years correspond to centres of 99.7% probability range.

sec.title: Nomenclature
sec.p: The nomenclature of plant species follows Tutin et al. (1964–1980).

sec.title: Chronology
sec.p: The ten radiocarbon dates from soil profile bases cover the last three quarters of the Holocene (Table 2). The oldest soil profile from a flat foothill plain is dated to the Mesolithic (6420 cal. bc, late Boreal in profile S4 (40 cm)). Two samples were dated to the Bronze Age (1680 cal. bc, Subboreal in profile K7 and 815 cal. bc, older Subatlantic in profile K6 (100 cm)). Both profiles were situated near summits of sandstone hills.

Dates from other profiles belong to the Medieval and early modern periods (ad 1010 cal. in profile K3, ad 1220 cal. in profile K1, ad 1334 cal. in profile S4 (10 cm), ad 1425 cal. in profile K6 (20 cm), ad 1550 cal. in profile K5 and ad 1773 cal. in profile K6 (5 cm)). The last sample dated as subrecent (18th–20th centuries) was found in profile K4 in the vicinity of Hradčany village. This date corresponds well with hints of former human-made disturbances, e.g. mining of sand or tillage before subsequent tree planting.

The dating of profile K6 was more detailed, because this profile contained the deepest pedoanthracological record. Four samples covering the period from the Preboreal to the Subboreal (200–60 cm) were dated in the Voroněž profile (see Figure 3). The upper part of the profile (55–0 cm) was formed in the subrecent period.

sec.title: Anthracological results
sec.p: A total of 5639 charcoal fragments from 12 soil profiles and 384 charcoal fragments from humolit profile Voroněž have been analyzed; the results are summarized in Figures 2 and 3, and Table 1. The samples were dominated by Pinus sylvestris. A firm preponderance of Scots pine over other species was visible in all samples. The proportion of pine charcoal fluctuated between 75% and 100% (88.8% on average).

Voroneˇž, survey pollen and charcoal diagram, combining the results of both pollen (curves) and charcoal (histograms) analyses.

sec.p: Other woody species occurred only in small quantities (Figure 2). Most of them are light-demanding species of semi-open woodland (Betula sp., Corylus avellana, Juniperus communis, Quercus sp., Sorbus sp., Vaccinium sp.). Four species (Abies alba, Fagus sylvatica, Picea abies and Tilia sp.) are strongly shading climax trees.
Besides Scots pine, the most common species in our samples were Vaccinium sp. (3.9%), Picea abies (2.1%), and Quercus sp. (1.3%). These tree species along with pine comprised 93% of the charcoals.

We found only small differences in species composition between samples obtained from the same depth, between complete profiles and between all samples in total. The abundance of Fagus sylvatica and Abies alba increases only in the modern period, these taxa being concentrated in profiles S1, S2 and S3 from the former village of Strážov. The distinctive composition in these profiles is probably the result of preferential burning of some species for fuel, e.g. in glassworks.

According to calculated anthracomass (Table 1), differences among individual charcoal samples indicate that fire impact varied considerably in time and space. Profiles with variable values are more numerous than profiles with stable high or low values.

Pedoanthracological data are supplemented with the pollen and charcoal analyses of the Voroněž peat profile (Figure 3). This profile is situated at the border of a fen wetland and a rocky slope. According to the pollen record, pine dominated here from the Preboreal to the Subboreal. Microcharcoal fragments were present continuously in this period, and macrocharcoal remains of Pinus sylvestris, Betula sp., Picea abies and Vaccinium sp. occurred abundantly. Pollen of broadleaved forest species, such as Corylus avellana, Tilia sp. and Quercus sp., was common especially during the middle Holocene, but their macrocharcoal remains were found only sporadically.

sec.title: Determination of charcoal
sec.p: Distinguishing small charcoal fragments of Picea abies from Larix decidua is difficult (Talon, 1997). In addition, Pinus sylvestris charcoal might be confused with P. cembra, P. mugo and P. uncinata agg. (=P. rotundata Link; Skalický, 1988). However, Larix decidua, Pinus cembra, and P. nigra, which are restricted to the Alps and Carpathians, have never been found in the Czech lowlands since the Lateglacial (Jankovská, 2007, Kuneš et al., 2009). The possibility of the former occurrence of Pinus mugo and P. uncinata is highly unlikely considering their restriction to subalpine belts and raised bogs, respectively.

sec.title: Reliability of results
sec.p: In comparison to similar pedoanthracological studies the data used are rich enough (12 profiles, 54 samples, 5639 pieces of charcoal, and 10 radiocarbon dates). In fact, direct evidence about the early Holocene in our profiles is based only on one of the seven dated samples. However, all obtained anthracological samples are similar to each other, at least with regard to the considerable dominance of pine. We noted no sign of the fossil presence of other vegetation types, perhaps with the exception of modern samples from former Strážov village/glasswork containing a portion of beech and fir. But this calorific wood was probably transported from distant beech-dominated forests on volcanic hills.

Continuous presence of pine woodlands from the Boreal to the present time is the most simple explanation for the anthracological record, and we found no indication that the detected presence of pine forests in the Boreal is an occasional exception. Younger charcoal remains are more abundant than older ones since destruction increases with time. However, we cannot exclude the possibility that the frequency or extent of fires increased during the Holocene.

Studies on modern wildfires have shown that there is a good correlation between charcoal and vegetation in the absence of any transport (Scott et al., 2000). There is also a close relationship between the occurrence of local fires and peaks in macroscopic charcoal (Gardner and Whitlock, 2001). However, Scots pine is more flammable than spruce (Engelmark et al., 1993) or broadleaved trees (such as oak), therefore the dominance of pine deduced from charcoal data might be partially overestimated.

sec.title: Comparison to present vegetation
sec.p: All profiles were located in a continuous area of pine forests characterized by the dominance of pine, the common occurrence of spruce and Vaccinium sp., and the scarcity of broadleaved trees. This vegetation corresponds well to our anthracological data even though spruce and beech seem to be less abundant in the fossil vegetation. In terms of phytosociology, the current pine forest can be classified into several communities (Leucobryo-Pinetum, Peucedano-Pinetum and Vaccinio uliginosi-Pinetum), but it is hardly possible to distinguish fossil pine communities based on our charcoal data. The fossil presence of Juniperus communis and Sorbus sp. as well as the absence of Calluna vulgaris may indicate a lack of extremely nutrient-poor habitats in the past. However, there is no evidence of the fossil occurrence of broadleaved or mixed (e.g. oak-pine) forests at the study site.

sec.title: Comparison to palaeobotanical analyses
sec.p: The anthracological results can be compared to the following palaeobotanical analyses from the Doksy region: (a) three palynological analyses made within 1 km of our profiles (Svitavská, unpublished data, 2011) including the detalied comparison with the Voroněž profile; (b) five palynological analyses representing more distant parts of the region (Jankovská, 1992; Abraham and Petr, unpublished data, 2011); (c) 12 simple palynological analyses made in the first half of 20th century (Firbas, 1927) and (d) three anthracological analyses from archaeological localities in rock shelters within the region (Opravil, 2003).

All analyses confirm the historic and ancient predominance of pine, although they show some additional local influences (e.g. alder carrs on peat, beech forests on volcanic hills). In total, the analyses jointly give a vivid account of the past vegetation. Pine forests formed a basic matrix which included isolated plots of other vegetation types; this pattern has survived up to the present.

Sandstone rock shelters were used by humans as an occasional refuge. Human settlement was recorded at such places for the Mesolithic, and rare human presence for the Neolithic, the Bronze Age, as well as the Hallstatt and La Tène periods (Matoušek et. al., 2005; Svoboda, 2003). The sediments of rock shelters were dated by archaeological methods and radiocarbon dating (Svoboda et al., 2007). In the samples from the Boreal, Pinus steadily dominated, whereas Quercus, Corylus, Tilia, Picea and Acer were rarely admixed. Rock shelters with archaeological deposits are usually situated close to watercourses. The composition of charcoal samples was probably influenced by the close proximity to watercourses with broadleaved trees, and also by people’s preferences for certain tree species.

sec.title: Fire ecology and forest regeneration
sec.p: The regeneration dynamics of the studied forest in many respects resembles the boreal forests of northern Eurasia. The persistence of pine-dominated forests results from cyclic succession initialized by human impact, small-scale gap dynamics and large-scale disturbances, such as fires, which significantly change the structure of stands.

Human pressure on the local forest landscape has been present since prehistory but increased at the end of the 13th century because of the high Medieval colonization of adjacent regions, and especially since the 19th century, when most stands were transformed with the help of modern forestry methods. Specialized activities, such as selective logging, clear-cutting, forest thinning, litter raking or resin and tar production are documented in the region since the Middle Ages (Meduna and Sádlo, 2009; Novák, 1971; Nožička, 1957; Schleger, 1976). However, our data show that despite human impact the composition of dominant species has remained nearly unchanged.

Semi-natural pine or pine/spruce forests are still preserved on rocky hills or in peaty hollows with low accessibility, e.g. in the vicinity of the K6 site. These stands are characterized by multilayered canopy, fallen timber, standing dead trees, complex age structure and traces of disturbances of various age, extent and origin including local fires. We found that pine trees older than 200 years frequently survive in such stands, whose age therefore exceeds the beginnings of modern forestry management in the region.

Natural gap dynamics is one of the major processes responsible for the regeneration of boreal forests (Kuuluvainen, 1994; McCarthy, 2001) and can be expected to occur also in the study area. The absolute majority of disturbances in recent semi-natural stands are small gaps emerging after the death of a single tree or several trees.

Fires in pine-dominated forests are regular but infrequent events and their effects seem not to be necessary for forest regeneration over long periods (Bendel et al., 2006). However, a high content of charcoal within all profiles indicates forest fires in the study area during a considerable part of the Holocene. Fire affects pine preferentially by killing other trees, moreover, pine seeds are more effective in the colonization of burned plots (Agee, 1998).

The species composition of the understorey probably also reflects fires as a controlling process. The studied forest includes species, such as Arctostaphyllos uva-ursi, Avenella flexuosa, Brachypodium pinnatum, Calluna vulgaris, Carex macroura, Chimaphila umbellata, Pteridium aquilinum, Pulsatilla patens, P. vernalis, Trientalis europaea, Vaccinium myrtillus and V. vitis-idaea, which are typical for post-fire succession in boreal forests in Northern Europe (Ruokolainen and Salo, 2006) or Western Siberia (Krasnoshchekov et al., 2010; Lytkina and Mironova, 2009) owing to their easy vegetative or generative post-fire re-establishment (Kalamees et al., 2005; Moog et al., 2002; Rowe, 1983; Schimmel and Granström, 1996; Uotila, 2005). Other fire indicators Geranium bohemicum and Tephroseris palustris (Esseen et al., 1997; Granström, 1993; Lytkina and Mironova, 2009) are extremely rare species (Holub and Procházka, 2000), which formerly also occurred in study area (Kochjarová and Hrouda, 2004; Slavík, 1997). The survival of these species can be facilitated also by forest thinning, pasturing and especially by litter raking. However, historical and archeological data do not mention the agricultural use of the studied forest. The stands were protected from these destructive influences by their owner in the last centuries (Sádlo et al., 2011; Schleger, 1976). Moreover, species supported by forest thinning or pasturing, such as Crataegus sp., Festuca rupicola, Fragaria viridis, Luzula luzuloides, Genista germanica, Prunus spinosa, Rosa canina and many others, are apparently uncommon in the study area.

sec.title: Vegetation stability in the Holocene
sec.p: Pine forests have probably been continuously present in the Doksy region since the early Preboreal, although our anthracological results support this hypothesis only for the period since the late Boreal. Scotch pine is a Pleistocene relict in central and southern Europe (Mirov, 1967), it was a dominant woodland species at lower altitudes of the Czech Republic in the Preboreal and Boreal (Kuneš et al., 2009). The abovementioned palynological analyses also support the early dominance of pine in the study area. They show Holocene maxima of pine from the Preboreal to the Boreal, whereas the dominance of broadleaved trees (such as elm, oak, and lime) starts only at end of the Boreal. Therefore, we suppose that pine forests directly replaced the vegetation of the open periglacial landscape and have existed without marked interruption or reduction since this period.

The studied pine forests were probably stabilized through repetitive disturbance events followed by phases of forest regeneration. Thus the stability of this ecosystem throughout the Holocene is a scale-dependent phenomenon resulting from cyclic vegetation processes on shorter timescales. The studied vegetation was doubtless influenced by fire since the Boreal and by woodcutting since at least the Middle Ages. The influence of windstorms or insect attacks as causes of disturbances followed by forest renewal cannot be excluded, either. Moreover, the role of human versus natural causes of these events cannot be assessed from our data. As is also the case for alpine timberlines (Novák et al., 2010; Talon, 2010), the relative importance of natural effects and human activity in vegetation dynamics in individual phases of the Holocene cannot yet be resolved because of their integrated effect. We believe that pine forests were often burned by humans for various reasons during the entire Holocene, although the hypothesis of anthropogenic pressure upon the vegetation is not necessary, as wildfires caused by natural processes are sufficiently common here. This type of vegetation occasionally burns from natural causes nowadays as well. Local forest managers have recorded more than 20 forest fires during the past 20 years in the study region. Small fires affecting a few tens of square metres have been even more frequent. Wildfires arising from storms in inaccessible rocky or swampy places are also abundant.

sec.title: Pine forests as vegetation relicts
sec.p: The term relict applied to vegetation at the Holocene scale is necessarily problematic as a result of the historical instability of species composition. The proportion of original species gradually declines in each vegetation unit defined on the basis of its species structure. A vegetation unit can be considered as a relict if this species attrition is extremely slow so that the present species composition still resembles its original status. However, with few exceptions (e.g. Kloss, 2005; Wilmanns, 1997) information on the composition of fossil communities is poor and sketchy.

Some pine forests are often considered to be vegetation relicts by many botanists in Central Europe (e.g. Heinken, 2008; Melnik, 1996; Muller, 1997; Walentowski et al., 2007). Generally, it is believed that these relict forests have persisted since the early Holocene being restricted to fragmented plots with extreme habitats (e.g. rocky slopes). The concept of relict status of pine forests was based mainly on the prevalence of these communities in the early Holocene, the steadily high representation of pine in palynological data from the subsequent phases of the Holocene and the occurrence of probable relict species. However, in the light of paleobotanical methods, some populations previously considered to be relicts were proved to be modern invasions (Latałowa 2001).

Direct evidence that pine forests endure without substantial changes of species composition had been lacking. Furthermore, the relict status was assigned only to stands on shallow and dry soils or wet peaty substrates. Pine forests in mesic conditions have been considered to be a product of forestry converting native broadleaved or mixed forests into plantations or a consequence of forest pasturing suppressing broadleaved trees in favour of pine (Ellenberg, 1996; Neuhäuslová, 2001; Walentowski et al., 2007).

The general concept of cultural replacement of broadleaved forests by pine forests is not necessarily inappropriate. However, our results imply that in extremely nutrient-poor habitats another scenario can exist, at least at a local scale. Pine forests occurring in a wide spectrum of hydric conditions can be regarded as early Holocene vegetation relicts there. Their vegetation structure has probably undergone some changes, but the dominance of pine and Vaccinium, the regular occurrence of spruce and a low share of broadleaved trees have remained constant. Some rare, continental floristic elements occurring in these communities (e.g. Astragalus arenarius and Carex macroura) are probably early-Holocene relicts; the local population of the latter species is c. 2800 km from its nearest localities in the Ural Mts (Sádlo et al., 2011).

According to our palaeobotanical results, the species composition of the forest is almost constant despite the fact that stands have doubtless been influenced by many human activities for several thousand years.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Terrestrial plant communities have the potential to respond to climate change either rapidly, if dominant species are killed by a series of extreme events, or slowly, if the cumulative effects of shorter-term climate fluctuations result in long-term compositional changes (Tweiten et al., 2009). Our results indicate the possibility of a third strategy, which minimizes responses to climatic fluctuations with the help of cyclic changes.

Some pine forests are often considered to be vegetation relicts by many botanists in central Europe (e.g. Heinken, 2008). Generally, it is believed that these relict forests have persisted since the early Holocene being restricted to fragmented plots with extreme habitats (e.g. rocky slopes). Pine forests in mesic conditions have been considered to be a product of forestry converting native broadleaved or mixed forests into plantations (Neuhäuslová, 2001). In this paper, we have confirmed the survival of pine forest relicts on a large spatial scale. Our new findings are that this relict vegetation includes also (a) mesic habitats and (b) cultural stands originating from natural ones and recently managed by forestry. The large-scale stability of pine forests during most of the Holocene implies that this vegetation can be interpreted as a historic relict of ancient boreal forests, and a geographically disjunct analogy of recent boreal forests in northern Eurasia.
